posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: When characterizing an arm I’ve never quite got an understanding as to what to do with this value.  Is it for reference or do I actively use it in my arm feedforward control

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: When determining kG  the sysid needs to know what horizontal is because kG is the voltage it takes to hold the arm steady at horizontal.   So you need to set that to whatever your encoder reading is when your arm is parallel to the ground.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So I would need to factor that in to the arm encoder measurement

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
This is not correct.  SysId determines the offset as a parameter of the fit - you do not need to tell it anything about the zero point.

You apply the value as an offset to the arm angle in the feedforward calculation.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
So either way it must be applied to the arm angle measurement.

No another question.  This is certainly supported using wpilib feedforward classes.  It looks like Phoenix 6 almost fully supports this in their slot configs.  They don’t seem to have an angle offset, but they do have a gravity type.

Does Rev support this in their pidf configurations?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

Does Rev support this in their pidf configurations?

No.

Note that the Phoenix 6 uses kG as a feedback term, rather than a feedforward one.  This is a bit less-stable but behaves much better when far from setpoint.  You can do the same thing with the WPILib ArmFeedforward class by passing in a measured angle instead of a desired one.

posts.cooked: Am I right in my characterization of CTRE ’s pid slots.  Almost completely supports it except for the angle offset?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I assume so, since that’s what the documentation says.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So when using sysId to characterize a CTRE arm I should be using an absolute encoder for arm position thereby getting the offset as close to zero as possible for use with CTRE

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I don’t see why you’d conclude that?  SysId does not care about linear displacement of the position data, because (as I said above) it estimates the zero point as part of the fit.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Right, but since CTRE ’s internal pid and feed forward controller doesn’t have a direct means of taking that into account wouldn’t the best strategy be to effectively eliminate that offset

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
The CTRE API allows you to set the zero position of any encoder to whatever you want.

The PID has nothing to do with this; error-based feedback cannot depend on the zero point of the angle measurement.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: One your first point:  Ah okay. On the second point.  I mentioned both aspects together because they are controlled together through CTRE ’s API.  I didn’t mean to confuse.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: Use the sensorToMechanismRatio in the config and the setPosition method to make sure that the position your TalonFx is reading matches the arm angle such that 0 rotations is horizontal. Then the built in kg should work.

posts.name: Stephen Peroni
posts.cooked: How would that physically work?  We have an arm of sorts (we call it a pivot) to adjust shot angle.  Vertical is its stowed/intake position, then we angle it from there for a shot or amp. We have a reverse limit switch wired into the talonfx set to zero the readings from a fused cancoder when the pivot hits a mechanical hardstop and limit switch in the vertical position.   We believe zeroing would aid in reliability (especially if belt skips or something during a match).  However, during tuning, I feel a Kg term would be beneficial to the ease of reliably tuning the pid values.  we are doing motion magic.  If we hold the arm horizonal and zero it, then when we hit the limit won’t the  readings rezero again and mess stuff up?  should we turn that off the auto reset to 0 off  and go with 0 at horizontal then establish setpoints from there?

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
First off, my general recommendation is to not try to code around mechanical issues vs fixing those issues directly. If you’re using a FusedCANCoder I would generally think that you shouldn’t need a zeroing routine. If you have a mechanical powertrain issue between the motor and sensor where something is skipping or slipping, I would advise trying to find a mechanical solution to that problem.

Second, you can still rezero your pivot against a hardstop, since you know what angle that hardstop is at. For example, our shot angle hits a mechanical hardstop around 18 degrees. We run a homing routine to stall against the hardstop for a bit and then “rezero” it by resetting its angle to the known hardstop angle. In practice, the only thing that really cares about the measured angle of the shooter tilt matching the real world is the kg term accounting for gravity. Most other applications care much more that angle measurements are consistent and repeatable, even if they are slightly offset from reality.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Okay.  This response confused me a little.  I don’t see why kG differs whether its applied as feedback or feedforward since it’s an additive term.  I’m assuming a mixed feedback/feedforward system in my thinking.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Calculating gravity compensation based on the current measured angle is a different control strategy than calculating it from the current desired angle.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Ah.  So an elevator kG would be fine, but the setpoint for arm kG would be different.  That was my thought earlier.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

So an elevator kG would be fine

I’m not sure what you mean by this - fine for what?  There’s no measurement or setpoint involved in an elevator kG, so the distinction there doesn’t exist (it’s probably more natural to call this case a feedforward).

Both feedforward and feedback can work well for gravity compensation on an arm.  They have different costs and benefits. CTRE uses feedback, while the default WPILib examples use feedforward (though the ArmFeedforward class is capable of doing either).
